journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part J: Journal of Engineering Tribology

title-group.article-title: Slurry erosion studies of hydroturbine steels under hydroaccelerated conditions

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical & Industrial Engineering, Baba Banda Singh Bahadur Engineering College, India
2School of Mechanical, Materials & Energy Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, India
3Department of Mechanical Engineering, University Institute of Engineering & Technology, Panjab University, India
4Department of Mechanical Engineering, Sant Longowal Institute of Engineering & Technology, India

author-notes.corresp: Harpreet Singh, School of Mechanical, Materials & Energy Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Ropar, Rupnagar, India. Email: harpreetsingh@iitrpr.ac.in

abstract.p: Degradation of the hydroturbine components due to slurry erosion is a serious issue, especially for the hydropower plants situated on the rivers originating from Himalayas in India. In the current investigation, slurry erosion performance of two stainless steels (CA6NM and CF8M), which are commonly used in hydroturbine power plants, has been studied. A high-speed erosion test apparatus was used for the studies. Slurry collected from an actual hydropower plant was used as the abrasive media in the test apparatus. The effect of slurry concentration (ppm), average particle size of slurry particles and rotational speed on the slurry erosion behaviour was investigated under different experimental conditions. The analysis of eroded samples was done using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and stylus profilometry. SEM images showed signatures of formation of lips, ploughing, crater and microcutting on eroded surface of steels.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Wear may be defined as damage to a solid surface caused by the removal or displacement of material by the mechanical action of a contacting solid, liquid or gas.1 Figure 1 shows the wear classification based on the work of Budinski.2 Budinski categories wear processes into four, namely abrasion, erosion, adhesion, and surface fatigue. Slurry erosion occurs when a solid–liquid mixture, specifically known as slurry, causes wear.3 This is common phenomenon in hydroturbine underwater parts and many other related industrial situations.4 Slurry erosion is a complex process consisting of interaction of three co-existing phases, namely carrier liquid, hard solid particles and the metallic surface in many ways.5 Major factors effecting erosive wear rate are (1) the hardness, shape, size and concentration of erosive particles; (2) the angle of impingement; (3) the fluid flow exposure conditions (laminar, turbulent) and (4) the physical (surface roughness), chemical and mechanical properties (toughness, hardness, etc.) of the targeting component.6–8 Figure 1.
Major categories of wear based on abrasion, erosion, adhesion, and surface fatigue.2

CF8M and CA6NM stainless steels (ASTM A743-grade) are iron–chromium–nickel–molybdenum alloys that are hardenable by heat treatment. Major applications of these alloys have been in large hydroturbine underwater parts for power generation.9 This is due to their good mechanical properties and resistance against corrosion and erosion.4 However, CA6NM, especially with large-size sections, exhibits anisotropic hardness10 and these steels have not performed well because deteriorating effects were observed when subjected to water with excessive solid contents.11,12 To study the failures or material removal mechanisms, a lot of research has been done in this field by various researchers. In most of the studies, simple rectangular shape specimens fitted at a particular angle at a time have been simulated in the laboratory using jet or pot-type tester. Little information is available in the open literature on the cylindrical shape specimen of these hydroturbine materials when exposed to slurry erosion conditions in a high-speed slurry erosion tester. The condition of erosion in this test rig is expected to be very similar to those prevailing in actual hydroturbines.

The evaluation of slurry erosion behaviour of materials under actual service conditions is often a difficult task, due to interactive effects of different parameters such as slurry concentration, velocity and properties of abrasive medium on wear rate. Accelerated erosion testing of materials can be performed by increasing load, velocity and other operational parameters in a laboratory test rig, where real contact conditions can be simulated. The aim of this study is to investigate the slurry erosion behaviour of two commonly used hydroturbine stainless steels (CF8M and CA6NM) under the hydroaccelerated conditions using a high-speed erosion test rig and slurry actually collected from one of the hydropower plants situated in the Himalayan region.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p:
CF8M and CA6NM stainless steels (ASTM A743-grade) which are commonly used in hydropower plants were selected for this research study. The chemical composition of CF8M and CA6NM stainless is given in Table 1. Hollow cylindrical specimens of external diameter 12 mm, internal diameter 6 mm and length 10 mm were prepared from the steels. Table 1.
Chemical composition of CF8M and CA6NM (ASTM A743-grade) steels.
Steel C max. Mn max. Si max. P max. S max. Cr Ni Mo Fe
CF8M 0.03 1.50 1.50 0.04 0.04 17.0–21.0 9.0–13.0 2.0–3.0 Balance
CA6NM 0.06 1.00 1.00 0.04 0.03 11.5–14.0 3.5–4.0 0.04–1.0 Balance

sec.title: Slurry erosion testing
sec.p:
A high-speed erosion test rig (DUCOM TR401) was used to study the slurry erosion behaviour of steel specimens. The test rig consists of various components such as slurry abrasion chamber, slurry tank, rotor and controller, as shown in Figure 2. The slurry abrasion chamber encloses the test specimen and slurry. Slurry tank is a cylindrical stainless steel vessel, in which the slurry is prepared to the required concentration. Three inlet and three outlet pipes are provided between slurry abrasion chamber and slurry tank for re-circulation of slurry. The rotation of rotor is such that slurry from slurry tank flows from top chamber towards the downward direction and used slurry leaves from bottom chamber to enter the slurry tank, thus ensuring continuous re-circulation of slurry. This high-speed erosion test rig is capable of creating accelerated erosion of standard test specimens with water-containing abrasive particles of controlled size and composition (slurry). One of the advantages of this rig is that, 12 specimens may be tested at a time. This ensures zero tolerance to the change of experimental conditions during the comparison of slurry erosion testing of different specimens under similar experimental conditions. The effect of average particle size, concentration (ppm) and velocity has been studied by several researchers and showed that these are significant factors, which can affect the erosion phenomenon. In order to study this, slurry collected from an actual hydroelectric power plant, namely Nathpa Jhakri, India, was dried and sieved into different size ranges. After mixing them in various proportions (Table 2), two different slurry concentrations having average particle sizes 100 and 300 µm were prepared. The morphology of slurry has been studied by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, JEOL JSM-6610LV). Figure 3(a) and (b) shows irregular and sharp-edged slurry particles with average particle sizes 100 and 300 µm, respectively. Tests were carried under different concentrations (10,000 and 30,000 ppm), erodent average particle size (100 and 300 µm) and rotation speed (2250 and 4500 rpm) to study the erosion performance of D-gun sprayed coating and substrate steel. Figure 2.
Schematic diagram of high-speed erosion test rig used for current investigation. Figure 3.
SEM morphology of slurry particles having average particle size (a) 100 µm and (b) 300 µm. Table 2.
Sieve analysis of slurry used in the current investigation.
BSS no. Multiplier Wt used (g) Multiplier × wt used Wt used (g) Multiplier × wt used
30 20 50 1000 200 4000
44 30 50 1500 200 6000
60 44 100 4400 200 8800
100 60 150 9000 200 12,000
160 100 150 15,000 200 20,000
200 160 150 24,000 – –
300 200 150 30,000 – –
<300 300 200 60,000 – –
Total 1000 g Total 144,900 Total 1000 g Total 50,800
AFN = 14,4900/1000 = 144.9 AFN = 50,800/1000 = 50.8
BSS No. 144.9 ≈ 100 µm BSS No. 50.8 ≈ 300 µm

A typical erosion test cycle began with the mounting of cylindrical specimens to the rotor assembly in slurry chamber. Care was taken to prevent over-tightening of clamping screws, which could induce compressive stresses in the specimens. After completing the slurry erosion testing cycle of 1 h, specimens were removed from the rotor assembly, gently brushed and cleaned with acetone in order to remove attached sand particles if any. The specimens were weighed before and after each slurry erosion cycle. The loss in mass of each specimen was recorded with the help of precision microbalance having an accuracy of 0.1 mg. As erosion is a surface phenomenon, so the peripheral surface area of each specimen was calculated by measuring the external diameter and length with the help of digital micrometer having an accuracy of 0.01 mm. Specific mass loss was calculated using the following relation
The slurry erosion process was repeated for six cycles for each of the samples.

To determine the effect of the chosen parameters, slurry erosion tests have been planned using Taguchi methodology, explained in Tables 3 and 4. Taguchi method consists of a plan of experiments with the objective of acquiring data in a controlled way, executing these experiments and analysing data, in order to obtain information about the behaviour of a given process.13,14 The results have been plotted as cumulative erosion (specific mass loss in g/m2) versus time of exposure (hours) in order to ascertain the kinetics of slurry erosion behaviour of CF8M and CA6NM stainless steels. After analysing the variance calculations based on average values which were obtained from 6 h of slurry erosion testing, the effect of concentration, average particle size and rotational speed on the said coatings has been studied. Table 3.
Parameters and their values corresponding to their levels used for the current experimentation.
Parameters Levels
I II
ppm 10,000 30,000
Size (µm) 100 300
rpm 2250 4500
Table 4.
Chosen L4 experimental plan.
Experiment no. Parameters and their levels
ppm Size rpm
1 I I I
2 II II I
3 I II II
4 II I II

sec.title: X-ray diffraction analysis of slurry
sec.p: X-ray diffraction (XRD) technique (made by PANalytical, Model: X’Pert PRO MRD) has been used to determine the chemical composition of the slurry used. XRD analysis of collected slurry has been done using Cu-Kα target (start position 20°, end position 120° and step size (0.0080)) with an X-ray tube voltage of 45 kV and a current of 40 mA.

sec.title: Surface roughness, microhardness measurements
sec.p: Slurry erosion affects the surface roughness of the specimen. Surface roughness of the steel specimens was measured using a surface roughness tester (made by Mitutoyo, Model: Surftest SJ 301). It consists of a diamond tip stylus, which is traversed at a constant slow speed across the steel specimen to measure the heights of the peaks and valleys, with a resolution of 0.01 µm having a cut-off of 0.4 mm.

Microhardness measurement was taken on the surface with a Vickers square pyramid diamond tip indenter at a load 9.80 N and dwell time 90 s using the Digital Micro Vickers Hardness tester (made by Chennai Metco, Model: SHV-1000). This tester is interfaced with an optical microscope. The two-diagonal width of the indentation was measured using a microscope at a magnification of 500×. The calculation of the Vickers hardness is calculated as follows
where HV, P and d represent the Vickers hardness value, the applied load (g) to cause the indentation and the average measured diagonal width (µm) of the indentation, respectively.

sec.title: XRD analysis of slurry
sec.p:
The XRD analysis of the slurry is shown in Figure 4. SiO2 (Vickers hardness 1030 HV15) was found to be the major phase in slurry. Another hard-phase Al2O3 having Mohs’ Hardness 916,17 was also found. The presence of other oxides such as MgO and CaO has also been indicated. Figure 4.
XRD spectra showing various phases present in slurry.

sec.title: Microhardness and surface roughness measurements
sec.p:
An average of 10 readings of microhardness for a given material has been reported in Table 5. The surface roughness data for the as-prepared and eroded CF8M and CA6NM stainless steels have been compiled in Table 5. It is obvious that the surfaces have become smoother as a consequence of slurry erosion, which is also quite understandable. If the extent of decrease in average surface roughness is measured for the CA6NM steel (13.81%) and CF8M steel (32.31%), it is evident that the CF8M steel has undergone higher percentage (%) reduction in Ra values in comparison with CA6NM steel. A similar trend of reduction in surface roughness (Ra) has also been shown by Curkovic et al.18 during the study on solid particle erosion behaviour of a high-purity, cold isostatically pressed ceramics, CIP-Al2O3. They have shown that alumina surfaces eroded with SiO2 at impingement angle of 30° possessed less roughness in comparison to starting (non-eroded) condition. Table 5.
Various characteristics of CA6NM and CF8M steels in as-prepared and eroded condition.
Property/material As-prepared CA6NM steel Eroded CA6NM steel As-prepared CF8M steel Eroded CF8M steel
Microhardness (HV9.803 N) 310 348 190 260
Surface roughness (Ra) 1.81 µm 1.71 µm (Expt 1) 1.30 µm 1.10 µm (Expt 1)
1.67 µm (Expt 2) 0.82 µm (Expt 2)
1.54 µm (Expt 3) 0.95 µm (Expt 3)
1.32 µm (Expt 4) 0.55 µm (Expt 4)
Average value 1.56 µm Average value 0.88 µm

sec.title: Slurry-erosion testing
sec.p:
The cumulative specific mass loss rate curves of the CA6NM and CF8M steel specimens for a total duration of 6 h of slurry erosion testing are shown in Figures 5 and 6. It can be seen that the overall specific mass loss rates of the CA6NM and CF8M steels are remarkably different. It has been observed that under all the investigated experimental conditions, specific mass loss was higher for CA6NM in comparison with CF8M steel. The maximum specific mass loss rate at the end of 6 h of slurry erosion testing for CA6NM and CF8M steel are 108.9 g/m2 (18.2 g/m2 h) and 222.8 g/m2 (37.2 g/m2 h), respectively. Evidently, CA6NM steel is found to have better slurry erosion resistance in comparison with that for the CF8M steel. This can be attributed to relatively higher hardness of CA6NM steel (Table 5). Moreover, for all the CA6NM steel cases, the rate of specific mass loss (g/m2 h) was initially higher, which generally decreased during later hours of testing. As the specific mass loss is affected to a large extent by the shape of slurry particles, changes in the slope of mass loss curves were also evident. Original slurry particles due to lot of microcutting edges have the ability to remove more material than the used slurry, which have only rounded edges, thus minimizing wear during later time of testing. Enhanced wear rate during initial hours of exposure could also have been partly due to rapid erosion of the microhills (surface roughness) present on the surfaces. This may be regarded as the transient state of erosion. However, once the surfaces are smooth, the erosion may achieve what we call steady state of erosion. During steady state, the rate of erosion is found to be constant. On the other hand, the erosion rate for the CF8M steel has not achieved steady state during the given period of exposure. It is also observed that with the increase in value of any of the investigated parameters (accelerated condition), there is increase in specific mass loss rate in both the steels. Figure 5.
(i) Cumulative mass loss (ii) mass loss rate vs. time plots for CA6NM and CF8M steel at (a) 2250 rpm with slurry of 10,000 ppm concentration and average particle size 100 µm and (b) 2250 rpm with slurry of 30,000 ppm concentration and average particle size 300 µm. Figure 6.
(i) Cumulative mass loss (ii) mass loss rate vs. time plots for CA6NM and CF8M steel at (a) 4500 rpm with slurry of 10,000 ppm concentration and average particle size 300 µm (b) 4500 rpm with slurry of 30,000 ppm concentration and average particle size 100 µm.

sec.title: Effect of slurry concentration
sec.p:
The effect of slurry concentration on the slurry erosion rate is shown in Figure 7(a). Figure 7(a) depicts that slurry concentration significantly contributes to the erosion. This may be due to the change in interaction areas or interaction time of slurry particles with the specimen during the change of concentration. Slurry erosion rate increases by 118% of CA6NM steel and 94% of CF8M steel with the increase in the concentration from 10,000 to 30,000 ppm. The results follow the expected trend quoted in the literature. The figure shows that CA6NM steel offers two times the slurry erosion resistance in comparison with CF8M steel. Figure 7.
Mass loss rate behaviour of CA6NM and CF8M steels under the effect of (a) slurry concentration, (b) average particle size and (c) rotational speed.

sec.title: Effect of average particle size
sec.p: The effect of average particle size is shown in Figure 7(b). One can observe that particle size contributes to specific mass loss. When the particle size was increased from 100 to 300 µm, the specific mass loss was higher. It can be seen from the figure that this effect is comparatively lesser dominating in the CF8M steel. The trends show that the overall specific mass loss rate of CA6NM steel was lower by a factor of 2 compared to CF8M steel after testing for 6 h. The effect of average particle size is more pronounced in the CA6NM steel. This may be due to more roughness of CA6NM steel. Gupta et al.19 also observed similar trends during the slurry erosion testing on brass and mild steel in the pot tester.

sec.title: Effect of rotational speed
sec.p: Figure 7(c) shows the effect of increasing the rotational speed on the specific mass loss of CF8M and CA6NM steels. With the increase in rotational speed, an increase in the slope of the specific mass loss lines can be seen. Figure 7(c) also shows that specific mass loss rate of CA6NM steel was lower by a factor of 2 in comparison with the CF8M steel after testing for 6 h. The increase in the specific mass loss with increase in rotational speed may be due to interaction of specimen with more slurry particles for the same time. Moreover interaction force between the specimen and the particles may also be larger due to the larger colliding speed. Existing theories also predict a similar relationship between the steady-state erosion rate Er and erodent velocity V such as (1) where K is a constant dependent on the properties of the erodent and target material and n the velocity exponent.

sec.title: Percentage contribution of each parameter
sec.p: The percentage contribution of each parameter to the slurry erosion rate of CA6NM and CF8M steels is also analysed. After analysis of variance calculations, for CA6NM steel: the most significant parameter found to be concentration which accounted for 70.66% of the total, followed by rotation speed (22.69%), while average particle size of slurry contributed only 6.65%. On the other hand, in case of CF8M steel, concentration contributed 74.27%, average particle size contributed 25% and rotation speed contributed negligibly. Thus, the most effective parameter found is the slurry concentration. Due to high concentration of silt during rainy season, generally the hydropower plant has to be shut down. It should be noted that these percentage contributions of each parameter to the specific mass loss rate are only valid within the experimental parameter setting level ranges (Table 3).

sec.title: Material removal mechanism
sec.p:
In this investigation, cylindrical specimens were rotated in the chamber of high-speed slurry erosion test rig having non-corrosive slurry. This may cause erosion (effect of slurry flow) and abrasion damage (effect of slurry particles) to the specimen surfaces simultaneously or in quick succession. It may be assumed that during the rotation of the specimen, the interaction angle with slurry flow ranges from −90° to +90°, as shown in Figure 8. As reported in literature, the angle of incidence of the particles substantially influences the wear of materials and can change the wear mechanism. Figure 8.
Cylindrical specimen rotating in slurry chamber with different orientations.

In high-speed erosion test rig, some of the slurry particles hit against the curved surface of specimen with certain angle along the flow. Hitting force can be divided into two components.
Tangential component which is parallel to the surface of specimen has a cutting effect at the surface.
The perpendicular component can make the material to fail by fatigue or under plastic deformation.
Therefore, it can be thought that slurry erosion of the specimens is simultaneously occurring by cutting abrasion and deforming abrasion.

However, the predominance of either of the mentioned modes of material loss would depend on material-related and slurry-flow factors. The material-related factors are chemical composition (constituents, grain size etc.), surface condition, ductility, brittleness, hardness, toughness, etc. and slurry-flow factors are concentration, average size, velocity, etc.20 Wang and Hutchings21 reported that the mechanism of erosion is different for different sizes and shapes of abrasive particles.

To investigate the material removal mechanism, all the eroded specimens were examined under scanning electron microscope. The SEM features of eroded surfaces of both CA6NM and CF8M steels under different experimental conditions are shown in Figures 9 to 12. The texture of the surface of steel specimens (Figures 9 to 12) which are exposed to liquid–solid particle eroding media and as-prepared steels are quite different. It is observed that the surface of each eroded sample is relatively smooth. These observations are also in agreement with the profilometry data (Table 5). Figure 9.
SEM features of eroded surfaces at 2250 rpm with slurry of 10,000 ppm concentration and average particle size 100 µm: (a) CF8M steel and (b) CA6NM steel. Figure 10.
SEM features of eroded surfaces at 2250 rpm with slurry of 30,000 ppm concentration and average particle size 300 µm: (a) CF8M steel and (b) CA6NM steel. Figure 11.
SEM features of eroded surfaces at 4500 rpm with slurry of 10,000 ppm concentration and average particle size 300 µm: (a) CF8M steel and (b) CA6NM steel. Figure 12.
SEM features of eroded surfaces at 4500 rpm with slurry of 30,000 ppm concentration and average particle size 100 µm: (a) CF8M steel and (b) CA6NM steel.

Due to (1) the large difference between hardness of slurry particles and specimen surface and (2) depending upon the position and size of slurry particles, lips (plastic deformation), microcutting, and craters (angularity of erodent supports the crater formation), would be easily created on the specimen surface, while flow of slurry helps in the removal of material from crater.

The SEM features of CF8M and CA6NM steels show microcutting, narrow craters or deep surface cavities and ploughing along with lip formation that are created by irregular-sharp edged slurry particles. Figures 9 and 12 show the formation of numbers of craters in CF8M and CA6NM steel specimens. Figure 10 shows the formation of larger numbers of lips in CF8M and CA6NM steel specimens. There is also increase in microhardness of surface of eroded surface of CF8M steel (Table 5). Thus, the mass loss may be due to shear cutting of the surface material, as well as, due to strain hardening and embrittlement of target material. Harsha and Bhaskar22 also observed similar features during solid particle erosion of ferrous and non-ferrous materials. Shivamurthy et al.23 studied the slurry erosive wear behaviour of 13Cr–4Ni steel using slurry jet erosion test rig and reported that microcutting and deep crater formation are the two main material removal mechanisms. Das et al.24 carried low stress abrasion studies on a hypereutectoid steel (specimens of different hardness) using a rubber wheel abrasion test apparatus and crushed silica sand under various loads and wheel speeds and reported the micropitting and microcutting dominant mechanisms for material removal from the specimens.

These steps signify composite ductile and brittle modes of material removal mechanisms, although the ductile mode is more dominant. The dominance of ductile mode is predicted from the evidence of large number of lips formed on the surfaces during slurry erosion, as seen by SEM analysis.

list-item.p: XRD analysis of collected slurry showed the presence of hard particles such as SiO2 and Al2O3 in the slurry.
CA6NM steel is found to have better slurry erosion resistance in comparison with that of the CF8M steel. This can be attributed to the higher hardness or toughness of the CA6NM steel.

During the slurry erosion of CA6NM steel, slurry concentration and rotational speed were found to be more dominant parameters in comparison with average particle size. On the other hand, in the case of CF8M steel, slurry erosion rate was found to be independent of average particle size of the slurry.
Profilometry data and SEM of eroded specimens showed the smoothness on the surfaces.
Signatures of formation of lips, ploughing, shearing of platelet, formation of crater and microcutting were observed on the eroded surface of CF8M and CA6NM steels.
